Beyond mining, the burning of coal releases pollutants that contribute to severe respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, including lung cancer and heart disease. According to comprehensive studies, the health impacts from coal pollution—such as from particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen oxides—lead to hundreds of thousands of premature deaths annually.

When these deaths are normalized by the amount of energy produced, coal comes out far worse than nuclear. For every terawatt-hour of electricity generated, coal is associated with many more fatalities than nuclear. This is because nuclear power does not involve the large-scale combustion of fuel, and it has a very low rate of fatal accidents in normal operations.

In conclusion, when considering all stages of the energy production process—including mining, transportation, and emissions—coal causes significantly more deaths per unit of energy than nuclear power.
